results.title: Indigenous Voices on the Screen with Professor Gary Foley
results.brief_description: Gumbainggir activist, academic, writer and actor, Professor Gary Foley charts the intersection of Indigenous activism and the world of film and TV in this short film by Yaegl director, producer and storyteller Pauline Clague.

constellations_primary.name: Black Power through film and TV
constellations_primary.description: The Black Power movement of the late 1960s and early 70s was “the most exciting and dynamic era in modern Indigenous history” according to Aboriginal activist Professor Gary Foley, who gained widespread attention for protests during the time and later leveraged film and TV to fight for Indigenous rights.

results.title_for_label: Indigenous Voices on the Screen with Professor Gary Foley
results.description:
Gumbainggir activist, academic, writer and actor, Professor Gary Foley charts the intersection of Indigenous activism and the world of film and TV in this short film by Yaegl director, producer and storyteller Pauline Clague. Through interviews, archival footage and scenes from film and TV, Foley explores the Black Power movement and the period during the 1970s and 80s when First Peoples began taking control of their representation in Australian screen culture, as well as how the moving image has been used to advocate for Indigenous Rights.

“It has been a journey recording Gary about the early years of film. How do you fit the wealth of information into an eight-minute space? I have had the privilege of recording many of the Indigenous trailblazers of the early years of television and film and know how important it is for us to remember those who made a mark on our landscape for us to dream, to make the films and stories we do now. As a person who loves their craft, I hope this gives you a glimpse of the power of our voices on-screen.” – Pauline Clague
description_for_label:
Gumbainggir activist, academic, writer and actor, Professor Gary Foley charts the intersection of Indigenous activism and the world of film and TV in this short film by Yaegl director, producer and storyteller Pauline Clague. Through interviews, archival footage and scenes from film and TV, Foley explores the Black Power movement and the period during the 1970s and 80s when First Peoples began taking control of their representation in Australian screen culture, as well as how the moving image has been used to advocate for Indigenous Rights.

“It has been a journey recording Gary about the early years of film. How do you fit the wealth of information into an eight-minute space? I have had the privilege of recording many of the Indigenous trailblazers of the early years of television and film and know how important it is for us to remember those who made a mark on our landscape for us to dream, to make the films and stories we do now. As a person who loves their craft, I hope this gives you a glimpse of the power of our voices on-screen.” – Pauline Clague

results.title: Judy (Mia Wasikowski) puppeteer costume and double's duplicate
results.credit_line:
Cutting by Julie Skelton

Construction by Lyn Molloy

Courtesy Vice Media LLC, Blue-Tongue Films and Pariah Productions
results.brief_description: When costume designer Edie Kurzer was crafting the jacket Judy (Mia Wasikowska) wears while performing in puppet shows, she had to create not only something bold that would set the star apart, but also something that would fit the character Polly (Lucy Velik).

constellations_primary.name: Like a puppet on a string
constellations_primary.description: From the silly to the sinister, puppets, muppets, dummies and toys on-screen.

results.title_for_label: Judy (Mia Wasikowski) puppeteer costume and double’s duplicate
results.description: When costume designer Edie Kurzer was crafting the jacket Judy (Mia Wasikowska) wears while performing in puppet shows, she had to create not only something bold that would set the star apart, but also something that would fit the character Polly (Lucy Velik). This meant Kurzer needed to design a piece that would fit two different builds. A double of the jacket with just the sleeves was also made for stand-in puppeteers, who were filmed during close-ups of the characters’ hands. Having a second costume for stand-ins saves time while shooting so that the main actor doesn’t need to stop working to give a double their costume.
description_for_label: When costume designer Edie Kurzer was crafting the jacket Judy (Mia Wasikowska) wears while performing in puppet shows, she had to create not only something bold that would set the star apart, but also something that would fit the character Polly (Lucy Velik). This meant Kurzer needed to design a piece that would fit two different builds. A double of the jacket with just the sleeves was also made for stand-in puppeteers, who were filmed during close-ups of the characters’ hands. Having a second costume for stand-ins saves time while shooting so that the main actor doesn’t need to stop working to give a double their costume.

Courtesy Vice Media LLC, Blue-Tongue Films and Pariah Productions

results.title: Bophana
results.brief_description: Bophana Audiovisual Resource Center in Cambodia is dedicated to the collection, digitisation and preservation of media lost during the Khmer Rouge reign, including newsreels, features, records, documentaries and photos.

constellations_primary.name: Bophana: cultural memory on film
constellations_primary.description: Bophana Audiovisual Resource Center is dedicated to the collection, preservation and presentation of audiovisual material related to Cambodia. Their collection includes archival footage, newsreels, documentaries, feature films, photographs and vinyl records.

results.description:
Bophana Audiovisual Resource Center in Cambodia is dedicated to the collection, digitisation and preservation of media lost during the Khmer Rouge reign, including newsreels, features, records, documentaries and photos. The 1960s and early 70s were a golden age for Cambodian cinema. The thriving film industry produced over 300 films and cinemas dotted the country alongside a vibrant music scene and traditional ballet. When the Khmer Rouge took over in 1975, artists were targeted and a key aspect of Cambodia’s cultural heritage was dismantled. Safeguarding this material is essential for reconstructing Cambodia’s cultural memory, allowing for new interpretations of historical footage and giving agency back to the community.

An institutional partnership between ACMI, Bophana and Cambodian Living Arts is supported by the Australian Government through the Australia-ASEAN Council of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade
description_for_label:
Bophana Audiovisual Resource Center in Cambodia is dedicated to the collection, digitisation and preservation of media lost during the Khmer Rouge reign, including newsreels, features, records, documentaries and photos. The 1960s and early 70s were a golden age for Cambodian cinema. The thriving film industry produced over 300 films and cinemas dotted the country alongside a vibrant music scene and traditional ballet. When the Khmer Rouge took over in 1975, artists were targeted and a key aspect of Cambodia’s cultural heritage was dismantled. Safeguarding this material is essential for reconstructing Cambodia’s cultural memory, allowing for new interpretations of historical footage and giving agency back to the community.

An institutional partnership between ACMI, Bophana and Cambodian Living Arts is supported by the Australian Government through the Australia-ASEAN Council of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade
